content.question: For a <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-distribution with sample size 10, <math alttext="the probability that, t is greater than or equal to 1.96, is approximately equal to 0.0408" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mi>P</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>≥</mo><mn>1.96</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>≈</mo><mn>0.0408</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="the probability that, t is less than or equal to negative 1.96, is approximately equal to 0.0408" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mi>P</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>1.96</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>≈</mo><mn>0.0408</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> . Which of the following is a property of the <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-distribution illustrated by the probabilities?

choices.label: With sample size 10, the tails of the curve of the <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-distribution have more area than the tails of the curve of the <math alttext="z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>z</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-distribution.

With sample size 10, the tails of the curve of the <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-distribution have less area than the tails of the curve of the <math alttext="z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>z</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-distribution.

With sample size 10, the middle of the curve of the <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-distribution has more area than the middle of the curve of the <math alttext="z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>z</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-distribution.

With sample size 10, the mean of the <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-distribution is greater than the mean of the <math alttext="z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>z</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-distribution.

With sample size 10, the mean of the <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-distribution is less than the mean of the <math alttext="z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>z</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-distribution.

content.answer: With sample size 10, the tails of the curve of the <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-distribution have more area than the tails of the curve of the <math alttext="z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>z</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-distribution.

topic.text: 7.2: Constructing a Confidence Interval for a Population Mean
